content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">    <title>jpylyzer</title>  <link href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//" rel="self"/>  <link href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org/"/>  <updated>2014-11-20T11:45:29+00:00</updated>  <id>http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org/</id>  <author>    <name>National Library of the Netherlands / Open Preservation Foundation</name>    <email>johan.vanderknijff@kb.nl</email>  </author>     <entry>    <title>New location of source repository</title>    <link href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/11/20/New-location-of-source-repository"/>    <updated>2014-11-20T00:00:00+00:00</updated>    <id>http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/11/20/New-location-of-source-repository</id>    <content type="html"> <p>As of today, the source repository of jpylyzer has moved to a new location:</p>  <p><a href="https://github.com/openpreserve/jpylyzer">https://github.com/openpreserve/jpylyzer</a></p>  <p>The reason behind this change is the recent <a href="http://openpreservation.org/news/open-preservation-foundation-launches-new-strategy-brand-and-website/">name change</a> of the Open Planets Foundation into the Open Preservation Foundation.</p>  <p>The <a href="https://github.com/openplanets/jpylyzer">old repo</a> is now empty, and only serves to redirect requests to the jpylyzer homepage through its old URL. From now on please do not use it for any commits or pull requests. We\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre aware that this is a bit inconvenient, but as it turned out it wasn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt possible to implement automatic redirects for <em>both</em> the repo <em>and</em> the homepage, so we opted to give priority to the homepage. This means that jpylyzer contributors may need to change their local repo settings. The easiest solution is probably to simply clone the repo from its new location.</p>  <h3 id="new-homepage-url">New homepage URL</h3> <p>Meanwhile the new URL for the jpylyzer homepage is: </p>  <p><a href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org/">http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org/</a> </p>  <p>The old URLs still work, but please use the new one when referring to jpylyzer.</p> </content>  </entry>    <entry>    <title>Jpylyzer finalist for Digital Preservation Awards 2014</title>    <link href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/09/11/Jpylyzer-finalist-dpa"/>    <updated>2014-09-11T00:00:00+00:00</updated>    <id>http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/09/11/Jpylyzer-finalist-dpa</id>    <content type="html"> <p>Today the <a href="http://www.dpconline.org/about">Digital Preservation Coalition</a> announced that jpylyzer has been selected as one of the finalists for the Digital Preservation Awards 2014. Jpylyzer is shortlisted for the <a href="http://www.dpconline.org/newsroom/latest-news/1272-dpa-2014-award-researchandinnovation-finalists">OPF Award for Research and Innovation</a>, which \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdrecognises excellence in practical research and innovation activities\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. </p>  <p>More information can be found here:</p>  <p><a href="http://www.dpconline.org/newsroom/latest-news/1271-dpa-2014finalists">http://www.dpconline.org/newsroom/latest-news/1271-dpa-2014finalists</a></p>  <p>Groovy!</p> </content>  </entry>    <entry>    <title>Changes to the User Manual</title>    <link href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/05/07/changes-user-manual"/>    <updated>2014-05-07T00:00:00+00:00</updated>    <id>http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/05/07/changes-user-manual</id>    <content type="html"> <p>Over the last weeks there have been some changes related to the jpylyzer User Manual. Here\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a brief overview.</p>  <h3 id="user-manual-now-part-of-website">User Manual now part of website</h3>  <p>The <em>jpylyzer</em> User Manual is now available online as part of this website. Check out the following link:</p>  <p><a href="http://openplanets.github.io/jpylyzer/userManual.html">http://openplanets.github.io/jpylyzer/userManual.html</a></p>  <h3 id="source-of-user-manual-now-in-markdown">Source of User Manual now in Markdown</h3>  <p>This is the first result of an effort to move jpylyzer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds documentation away from Microsoft Word: the source of the User Manual is now entirely written in <a href="http://michelf.ca/projects/php-markdown/extra/">Markdown Extra</a>, with some <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MathML">MathML</a> which is used for the equations.  With the <a href="http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/">Pandoc</a> tool the Markdown source can be exported to a wide variety of delivery formats.</p>  <h3 id="figures-as-svg">Figures as SVG</h3>  <p>In addition to this, the figures in the User Manual are now all available as editable <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalable_Vector_Graphics">Scalable Vector Graphics</a> files. These can be found (alongside the  Markdown source) in the Github repo:</p>  <p><a href="https://github.com/openplanets/jpylyzer/tree/master/doc">https://github.com/openplanets/jpylyzer/tree/master/doc</a> </p>  <p>These changes remove any dependencies on proprietary formats and tools. Hopefully this will make it easier for people to contribute to  jpylyzer and its documentation.</p>  <h3 id="status-of-pdf">Status of PDF</h3>  <p>The status of the <em>PDF</em> version of the Manual is a bit unclear at this stage: a first test at updating the <em>PDF</em> from the Markdown source resulted in  some issues (the main problem is that some of the tables are not properly fitted to the page), and I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm still looking for a solution for that.  Perhaps more importantly, I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm not sure if there\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds real <em>need</em> for a PDF version anymore. For now I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdll leave the old <em>PDF</em> (which is based on the Word document) online. Needless to say this is only a temporary solution (the Word document will eventually be removed from the repo altogether).</p>  </content>  </entry>    <entry>    <title>Release of jpylyzer 1.13.0</title>    <link href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/04/10/Release-of-jpylyzer-1-13-0"/>    <updated>2014-04-10T00:00:00+00:00</updated>    <id>http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/04/10/Release-of-jpylyzer-1-13-0</id>    <content type="html"> <p>Since it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds been quite a while since the previous binary release (which was version 1.10.1), here\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a brief overview of the main changes since that version:</p>  <h3 id="pretty-printed-output">Pretty-printed output</h3> <p>The most visible change is that <em>jpylyzer</em> now produces output as pretty-printed XML. If you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre using <em>jpylyzer</em> interactively, you can now inspect its output without the need to use a dedicated XML editor or viewer; just use any text editor you like. You can suppress pretty printing with the <em>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnopretty</em> option.</p>  <h3 id="improved-stability-in-case-of-malformed-images">Improved stability in case of malformed images</h3> <p>Andy Jackson of the British Library reported some <a href="https://github.com/openplanets/jpylyzer/issues/31">odd behaviour</a> with images that were (deliberately) malformed by flipping specific bit values. An analysis revealed a number of edge cases that would drive <em>jpylyzer</em> into an (almost) infinite loop. Although  you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre unlikely to run into such malformations with actual images that exist \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdin the wild\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, <em>jpylyzer</em> now handles these cases gracefully.</p>  <h3 id="extraction-of-null-terminated-xml-content">Extraction of null-terminated XML content</h3> <p>Old versions of certain <em>JPEG 2000</em> encoders would erroneously terminate embedded XML with a null byte. As this results in an XML (or UUID) box whose contents are not well-formed XML, <em>jpylyzer</em> doesn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt include the XML in its output if this happens. The new <em>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnullxml</em> option forces <em>jpylyzer</em> to extract the XML (minus the trailing null byte) in that case. The use of this option does <em>not</em> affect the validation outcome in any way.</p>  <h3 id="validation-of-codestream-comments">Validation of codestream comments</h3> <p><em>Jpylyzer</em> now includes a check on the presence of control characters in codestream comments.</p>  <h3 id="validation-of-url-box">Validation of URL box</h3> <p>URLs in the URL box must be terminated with a null-byte; <em>jpylyzer</em> now performs a check for this.  </p>  <h3 id="improved-handling-of-control-characters-and-utf-8">Improved handling of control characters and UTF-8</h3> <p>This release also fixes a number of minor bugs that are related to the handling of control characters in extracted content, and the subsequent encoding of extracted features as UTF-8 encoded text.</p>  <h3 id="miscellaneous-bugfixes-and-improvements">Miscellaneous bugfixes and improvements</h3> <p>In addition to the above changes, this release contains a number of small fixes, improvements and optimisations, most of which are invisible to the user. Also, the source code now (mostly) respects the conventions of the <a href="http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/">PEP 8</a> style guide, which should make it easier to read.</p>  <h2 id="improved-build-process-more-regular-releases">Improved build process, more regular releases</h2> <p>For some time the release schedule of binary packages for <em>jpylyzer</em> has been lagging behind the development version for quite a bit. The main reason for this was the somewhat awkward process for making the Debian packages: each release includes both 64 and 32 bit packages, each of which needs to be built on a different architecture.</p>  <p>A recent <a href="http://wiki.opf-labs.org/display/SP/SCAPE+Training+Event+-+Preserving+Your+Preservation+Tools">SCAPE training event</a> gave me the idea of creating each build using a dedicated virtual machine, which is pretty easy with <a href="https://www.virtualbox.org/"><em>VirtualBox</em></a> and <a href="http://www.vagrantup.com/"><em>Vagrant</em></a>. That didn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt <em>quite</em> work, as <em>VirtualBox</em> turned out to be unable to cope with any 64-bit virtual machines (which is probably a quirk of the host machine I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm using for the builds, which is quite old). In the end I decided on doing a clean install of <a href="http://www.linuxmint.com/release.php?id=18"><em>Linux Mint</em> 13</a> on the host machine (based on <a href="http://releases.ubuntu.com/12.04/"><em>Ubuntu</em> 12.04 <em>Precise</em></a>), and this machine is used directly for creating the 64 bit packages. The 32 bit packages are made on a virtual machine running the 32 bit version of <em>Ubuntu Precise</em>.</p>  <p>Finally the <em>Windows</em> executables are made on a separate machine, as always. Overall this results in a workflow that is reasonably straightforward. This should result in more regular binary releases from now on.</p>  </content>  </entry>    <entry>    <title>Launch of jpylyzer homepage</title>    <link href="http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/02/18/Launch-of-jpylyzer-homepage"/>    <updated>2014-02-18T00:00:00+00:00</updated>    <id>http://jpylyzer.openpreservation.org//2014/02/18/Launch-of-jpylyzer-homepage</id>    <content type="html"> <p>At long last <em>jpylyzer</em> has its own homepage. From now on these pages will be the main channel for updates on this tool. This also means that <a href="http://www.openplanetsfoundation.org/software/jpylyzer">the old <em>jpylyzer</em> page on the main site of the Open Planets Foundation</a> is now largely obsolete (we\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdll probably put a redirect there to the current pages).  </p> </content>  </entry>     </feed>
